title: My Child Is Scared of Math Tests – How to Help
description: Practical strategies for parents whose children experience test anxiety specifically around math assessments.
imageAlt: Child anxious about upcoming math test

content.intro: Test anxiety is real. For many kids, the fear isn't about not knowing math – it's about proving they know it under pressure. Here's how to help.

sections.text: Why Math Tests Cause More Anxiety
Compared to reading or social studies, math tests have unique pressure:

items: Right/wrong answers with no partial credit
Speed often matters
One missed step can cascade into wrong answers
Results are quantifiable – can't hide behind interpretation
Mistakes are obvious and feel embarrassing

rows: Rushing to finish and get it over with

items: Don't add pressure: "You need to do well on this"
Don't dismiss: "It's just a test"
Don't compare: "Your sister never worries about tests"
Don't over-prepare with last-minute cramming
Don't punish poor test performance
Prepare gradually over days, not hours
Practice in test-like conditions (timed, quiet)
Identify and address specific gaps
Create a simple study routine
Get good sleep and eat breakfast
Teach simple calming techniques (deep breaths)
Encourage positive self-talk ("I prepared for this")
Remind them to skip hard questions and come back
Don't discuss the test right before they take it
Have a normal morning routine
Focus on effort, not just score
Review mistakes as learning opportunities
Don't ask "How did you do?" immediately
Celebrate completion, regardless of outcome
Look forward to improvements, not backward at failures

sections.text: If anxiety is severe, talk to the school about accommodations. Many schools offer extended time or separate testing rooms for anxious students.
Test anxiety often stems from a shaky foundation. Kids who feel solid in their math skills are naturally less anxious. Build that foundation with:

items: Regular, low-pressure practice
Mastery-based learning (fully understand before moving on)
Positive math experiences outside of tests
Games and activities that build fluency

faq.question: Should I request a 504 plan for test anxiety?
faq.answer: If anxiety significantly impacts performance and daily life, it's worth discussing with the school. A 504 can provide accommodations like extended time, separate testing, or breaks.

faq.question: Does practicing more tests help with test anxiety?
faq.answer: Sometimes. Familiarity reduces anxiety. But if practice tests themselves cause anxiety, focus on building skills first, then gradually introduce timed practice.

faq.question: My child knows the material but blanks on tests. Why?
faq.answer: This is classic test anxiety. The stress response (fight-or-flight) literally interferes with memory retrieval. Relaxation techniques and building confidence can help.
